intro: Negundo aceroides subsp. interior, commonly known as the interior boxelder, is a deciduous tree native to the western United States. It belongs to the Sapindaceae family and is characterized by its compound leaves, which are typically three to five lobes. The tree produces small, yellowish-green flowers in clusters, followed by winged fruits that aid in seed dispersal. Its bark is smooth and grayish-brown, with shallow fissures, and it can grow up to 20 meters in height. This subspecies is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, making it a resilient tree in harsh climates.
